 ZAMBIA AGRICULTURAL SECTOR INVESTMENT PROGRAM I. BACKGROUND A. Introduction 1.1 The Agricultural Sector Investment Program (ASIP) described in this report is among the first in a new generation of investment operations that follow what is sometimes called an integrated sector approach. This approach, which aims at improving the effectiveness of public expenditures, has the following main characteristics (see para 2.1): * It covers all or most of the sector. * It is prepared by local stakeholders (the government, the private sector, and nongovernmental organizations). * It is supported by all donors active in the sector. * It minimizes reliance on international long-term consultants. * It involves common implementation arrangements. 1.2 The ASIP was initiated in Zambia in response to the strong dissatisfaction of both the Government and donors with the country's low agricultural growth rates. The low growth has been attributed to several causes. Past government policies were biased against agriculture and led to capital and labor disinvestment in the sector. The parallel management structures established for donor-supported projects and the heavy use of foreign consultants have hindered domestic capacity building. Moreover, development projects have been largely driven by donors, with the Government taking a responding rather than an initiating role. Considerable private investment at the farm level to rehabilitate capital stocks is needed to stimulate productivity and income growth. And this private investment needs to be complemented by public investment in key support services and rural infrastructure to improve and sustain the sector's supply response in the long-run. These issues are beginning to be addressed. The Government is rectifying policy weaknesses, and donors have agreed to greater collaboration. Through the ASIP, they will continue to tackle these issues.
 - 2 - Box I Why a sector approach in Zambia 's agriculture? Before preparation of the ASIP started in October 1992, there were about 180 donor- financed projects in Zambia's agricultural sector. Most had a separate, parallel management structure, involved little if any sense of local ownership, and relied extensively on expatriate consultants. The Government had only partial knowledge of these projects, their costs, and their accomplishments. The donor-financed salaries of project staff were higher than government salaries and created frictions. Moreover, the government had to dedicate much of its planning and management capacity to satisfying donors' varied requirements; that left its staff little time to develop their own initiatives or to improve efficiency. To remedy this situation, the Government urged a gradual phasing out of the existing project structures and encouraged closer collaboration among donors, to make aid more efficient. The Government took steps to increase Zambian ownership of development initiatives. In response, the Bank initiated consultations with donors that led to a consensus on the need for an integrated sector approach. As the first step toward adopting this approach, the Government appointed a Zambian task force, drawing from both the public and the private sectors, to prepare the ASIP. 1.3 With copper and other minerals accounting for more than 90 percent of its foreign exchange earnings, Zambia faces an urgent but daunting need to develop altemative exports to lessen its vulnerability to unfavorable changes in the copper market. Its agricultural sector has the potential to become a major source of foreign exchange eamings. Zambia's underutilized base of renewable natural resources is more than adequate to support rapid growth in agricultural production in the shortrun and to ensure the sustainability of agricultural income and exports in the longrun. About three-quarters of a million hectares of farnland in Zambia are underutilized or abandoned, and more than 90 percent of irrigable land is not irrigated. Agricultural sector characteristics and institutions are discussed in annex 12. B. Economywide context 1.4 The ASIP represents a major commitment by the World Bank and other participating donors in support of an initiative by the Government to comprehensively restructure the public sector's role in Zambian agriculture. Therefore, even though the ASIP is not a policy-based structural adjustment credit, it is important to analyze the economywide context of the program. This analysis below assesses: * Macroeconomic framework. * The role of agriculture in the economy. * Fiscal stability and the fiscal affordability of the program. * Private investment in agriculture. 1.5 Macroeconomic framework. Since Independence in 1964, Zambia relied very heavily upon planning and administrative controls to manage the economy. The public sector, especially parastatal enterprises, embarked on investments aimed at generating economic growth and employment while international borrowings were used to finance public sector investments
 - 3 - (frequently unproductive) and to support unsustainable levels of consumption. The economy's performance was also adversely affected throughout this period by its heavy dependence on copper whose real prices and production were declining, the latter as a result of insufficient investment to increase productivity and output. By late 1991, Zambia was suffering from high external debt burden (over US$7 billion), an inefficient and highly protected parastatal sector that dominated the economy, rapid declines in per capita income, increases in poverty, and unwillingness on the part of Government to take and hold to the policy decisions necessary to change the course of the economy. The election of the opposition party, the Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) in November 1991, was seen as an overwhelming endorsement of MMD's economic reform program whose objectives are to restore internal and external economic stability, change the way the economy is managed, get the Government and parastatals out of business activity, promote the private sector, and focus Government's efforts on the creation of a positive enabling environment for private-sector business and the provision of the necessary infrastructure and social services. 1.6 Since early 1992, Zambia's overall policy performance has been mixed, even though the implementation of the policy reform agenda has remained on course. The direction of policy has remained clear, and the progress has been steady. The pace of liberalization and decontrol has been good. In particular, Zambia's macroeconomic performance in terms of fiscal balance and money supply growth has been strong. As a result, inflation declined from an average annual rate of over 100 percent in the previous four years to an annual rate of 22 percent in the last half of 1994. Interest rates have also declined (from over 200 percent in April to about 25 percent in December 1994), and this has strengthened the Government's ability to maintain budget discipline and to control the deficit. The Government has decontrolled prices of all agricultural products and inputs, eliminated exchange rate restrictions, and liberalized export and import trade, and it completed several major privatizations in 1994. However, there are some policy fronts where progress has been less than satisfactory. The Government needs to do more in policy reforms related to parastatals, the financial sector, the civil service, the land market, and public sector investment. It also needs to accelerate the privatization program. The 1994-96 Policy Framework Paper (PFP), scheduled for Board consideration in April, spells out the Government's policy reform agenda. To complement the PFP, specific agricultural sector policy and institutional reforms that are required for further agricultural growth are contained in the Government's Letter of the Agricultural Sector Development Policy (see annex 1). The main areas of reform include additional market liberalization, privatization of agricultural parastatals, land use and tenure, and elimination of agricultural credit subsidies. 1.7 Despite significant progress on policy reform, the Zambian economy is still in a deep recession. Total GDP is estimated to have declined by 7.5 percent in 1994, partly because of a sharp drop in maize output, but also because of declines in copper output and manufacturing. In part, this is an inevitable result of the tight monetary policies required to fight inflation. In addition to these aggregate demand and financial sector problems, individual real sectors have had difficulties. Agricultural growth was impeded by poor rains. Manufacturing still suffers from transitional tax and tariff anomalies, and copper mining output has suffered from technical problems at the smelters. Continued strong fiscal performance and reduced inflationary expectations should permit increased liquidity in the financial sector in 1995. With this and the measures being taken to deal with tax and tariff anomalies, to attract private sector capital and management into copper mining, and to strengthen financial institutions, private investment should begin to recover in 1995, leading to a more vigorous supply response and economic growth.
 - 4 - 1.8 Zambia's ability to generate economic growth and new jobs will depend on Government's continued progress on a broad policy front. This includes: controlling inflation on a sustained basis; reducing the crowding out effect on investment in the private sector by reducing public sector claims on available resources; adjusting the trade and tariff regime to encourage efficient production; privatizing the parastatal sector; restructuring - and in some instances privatizing - the institutions mobilizing and allocating term resources, such as insurance companies and pension funds; reforming mining sector policies and investment incentives; and privatizing ZCCM and removing barriers to private sector investment in copper mining. 1.9 The role of agriculture in the economy. Agriculture figures large in Zambia's economy and is expected to play a critical role in its growth and restructuring even though the agricultural growth rates averaged 2.2. percent a year between 1965 and 1991, less than the population growth rate of 3.2 percent a year. This was largely because of the inappropriate government policies of the past (see para 1.6 and annex 1). The high inflation rates and the associated interest rates discouraged investments in agriculture while price controls of agricultural outputs resulted in adverse terms of trade. With improved agriculture sector policies, Zambia could greatly expand agricultural production. Productivity in the smallholder subsector which is considerably below the production frontier and the genetic potential of the crop varieties could be increased by 94 percent for maize and 85 percent for soybean (see table 2). Although agriculture accounts for only 18 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), this small share belies the extent to which Zambia depends on the sector. About 60 percent of the population depends on agriculture for livelihood. Agriculture employs about 67 percent of the labor force and remains the main source of income and employment for rural women. The increase in income of rural women will result in poverty reduction of the rural population. Besides, it will continue to provide most new jobs for at least the next decade, even with higher industrial growth rates, because of the country's small industrial base and declining mineral resources. With the favorable environment and dwindling mineral resources, agriculture is expected to become an increasingly important source of foreign exchange. In 1993 agriculture was the second major earner of foreign exchange for Zambia's non-traditional export with total foreign exchange earning of US$33.7 million. Agricultural issues have also figured prominently in the country's fiscal problems: subsidies to the sector averaged about 3 percent of GDP during 1983-91. These subsidies have been significantly reduced, and are being gradually phased-out. 1.10 Fiscal stability and the fiscal affordability of the program. To succeed, an integrated sector program such as the ASIP must be implemented in a fiscally stable environment and it should be affordable within the government's budget. Zambia's macroeconomic stability depends primarily on the Government's ability to control inflation, since exchange and interest rates are market-determined and tend to closely follow the domestic inflation rate. In turn, controlling inflation will depend on controlling the money supply and hence on containing the fiscal deficit. The Government has had a good record on fiscal control in the past three years with the notable exception of the first half of 1993. More than 18 months of solid fiscal and monetary performance have led to sharp deceleration of inflation, from a triple-digit rate to less than 20 percent in the second half 1994. Despite the effective fiscal control, reducing inflation took time because expectations of continuing inflation made it more difficult to bring consumer prices and real interest rates under control. 1.11 The available data show that the ASIP is fiscally affordable. Estimated government spending under the ASIP in 1996-99 is relatively low in absolute terms and well within historical levels of support for agriculture (table 1). They are also a very small share of total government spending. In the past, the Government financed an average of about 30 percent of total public
 expenditures in the agricultural sector, while the balance was financed by donors (major donors active in the agricultural sector are shown in table 3). Donor financing in the period between 1990 and 1993 amounted to US$469.3 million. The donor funds financed 100 percent of capital investments and about 90 percent of recurrent expenditures associated with donor-run projects. Since the future capital and recurrent expenditures of donor financed projects are usually preprogrammed, there is little uncertainty attached to their funding. However, the Government has experienced problems with meeting its counterpart funding obligations, due partly to the higher aggregate level of counterpart funding required to service the 180 donor-supported projects in the agricultural sector. Moreover, cost recovery of agriculture services has been low. During 1990-92 cost recovery of veterinary services was less than one percent of the cost of such services. This trend has changed partly because of the Government's decision to privatize those agricultural services that are better handled by the private sector and by increased enforcement of cost recovery measures. It is estimated that increased revenue collection from fees on veterinary services, land use services, agricultural training, and agricultural marketing and trade could finance up to 50 percent of government expenditures on the ASIP. Under the ASIP, the Government will increase its financing to about 40 percent of total agricultural expenditures, resulting in a steadily declining share for donors. This is because the ASIP would produce savings mainly by eliminating government subsidies for agricultural credit, and higher revenues from agricultural services through improved cost recovery measures. The elimination of duplication of donor support will also result in significant savings in government's counterpart funding. The combined effect of these savings will total $390 million over the period of 1995-99 (para 2.42). ASIP estimates exclude donor contributions and credit subsidies for crop purchases. 1.12 The private sector in agriculture. Zambia's agricultural strategy before 1992 was interventionist with direct involvement in agricultural production. This strategy included nationalization of maize mills and large farms, establishment of parastatals and state controlled cooperatives, and extensive regulation and subsidization of agricultural production, marketing and processing. This intervention distorted agricultural production patterns and discouraged the private sector from active participation. Since 1992, the Government has vigorously embarked on policies aimed at promoting private sector development, including privatizing agricultural activities and removing regulatory constraints. The Government is fully committed to rolling back the extensive involvement of the public sector in agricultural activities. Already four enterprises have been privatized and another twenty-three are at advanced stages of the privatization process (see annex 1). It is expected that when the privatization process is completed, most of the
 - 6 - services currently provided by the public sector, including veterinary services, will be carried out by the private sector. There are already signs that government measures have prompted increasing private investments in agriculture, particularly in high value export crops. Between 1992 and 1993, the export of roses increased by 84 percent from US$2.9 million to US$5.5 million. C. The potential for growth in agriculture 1.13 Zambia has the potential to greatly expand agricultural production. This potential resides primarily in the possibilities for increasing the utilization of available natural resources - particularly Zambia's abundant land and water resources - and the efficiency of their use. An analysis of Zambian agriculture in 1989 showed that, at market-determined exchange rates, the country has a strong comparative advantage in a range of food crops, industrial crops, and livestock products. This comparative advantage exists whether the sector continues to use present technology or invests in improved technology. For maize, cotton, sunflower, and tobacco, the estimated domestic resource cost ratios are less than 0.40 across the range of farm subsectors (smallholders, emergent farmers, and commercial farmers). This comparative advantage should enable Zambia to increase agricultural GDP and export earnings. Potential sources of growth 1.14 There are four main potential sources of agricultural growth: expansion of cultivated area, increases in yield, diversification, and improvements in livestock productivity. The potential for growth from these sources is strongest in the smallholder and emergent commercial farming subsectors. 1. 15 Expansion of cultivated area. Of Zambia's total cultivable land, only 14 percent is cropped each year. Expansion of cropped area has been the main source of agricultural growth in the past, and land would not be a binding constraint in the foreseeable future. Zambia's ability to achieve agricultural growth rates which are significantly higher than population growth rates would, however, require that the severe labor constraints in the traditional sector can be overcome through the introduction of new technology. Improvements in the production environment under the ASIP are expected to result in expansion of the area under cultivation by smallholders and emergent farmers as well as by commercial farmers. Key improvements will be in access to farm mechanization, particularly animal draft power, through the farm power and mechanization subprogram, and in extension and animal health services. 1.16 Increases in yields. Productivity in the traditional sector has remained stagnant over the past decade. It is considerably below the production frontier and the genetic potential of the crop varieties cultivated. Even modest increases in the productivity of smallholders, who produce most of the output, would have a significant impact on national agricultural growth. The favorable soil and rainfall conditions in much of Zambia offer considerable potential for improving yields using available technology (table 2).

Zambia's relatively large urban population and the export potential in Southern Africa should support diversification toward higher-value crops (such as sunflower, soybean and cotton), and livestock enterprises in peri-urban areas and along the Line-of-Rail and the major all-weather roads. Commercial farmers are expected to be the first to exploit this opportunity, but as small-scale irrigation develops, emergent commercial farmers will gradually increase production of high-value crops. The ASIP's irrigation and new products development subprograms would support the introduction of new technology and the identification of new crops and markets. 1.18 Improvement in livestock productivity. The potential for growth is high in the livestock subsector. In the traditional sector calving rates are 5 percent, compared with 13 percent in the commercial sector, takeoff is 6 percent (compared with 17 percent), and adult mortality rates are 9 percent (compared with 18 percent). Most of the difference in output can be explained by the poor animal husbandry practices of the traditional farmers. Given this slack capacity in the sector, productivity gains should be possible using existing technology. But achieving these gains will require public investment in farmer training and efficient delivery of improved animal health services. Demand for agricultural output 1.19 Growth in agricultural output will be driven by the expected increase in domestic demand for food. With estimated population growth of 3.2 percent per year and growth in the urban population from 50 percent to 60 percent of the total, food requirements are expected to increase sharply over the next decade. The income elasticity for food is about 0.90, and food accounts for 80 percent of expenditures by lower-income households. The effective demand for food is thus expected to remain high. And as the economy improves and per capita incomes increase, per capita consumption of higher-value food products is expected to grow. 1.20 Export demand also is expected to increase as a result of the removal of export restrictions on agricultural products and the introduction of a market-determined exchange rate. In 1993, with foreign exchange earnings of US$33.7 million, agriculture was the second major earner of foreign exchange for Zambia's non-traditional export. Soybean production in the commercial sector has increased dramatically over the past two years, to meet the excess demand in South Africa.
 Demand for maize exports to Malawi and Zaire is expected to continue growing as a result of population increase in Malawi and continued political instability in Zaire. In the longer run Zambia could become a major agricultural supplier in southern Africa given its land reserves, its relatively low cost of production, and the greater reliability of its rainfall patterns compared with those of the region's other agricultural surplus countries (South Africa and Zimbabwe). Zambia can also be competitive in meeting the increasing demand for specialty crops, including organically grown crops, in European markets. Two areas that have shown promise are the export of roses, which has increased more than fourfold between 1990 and 1993 from US$1.2 million to US$5.5 million, and the production of high-value food colorants from marigolds and paprika, which is expected to expand rapidly over the next two years. 1.21 Increased efficiency in the agricultural marketing system resulting from market liberalization would provide an additional stimulus to the growth of the agricultural sector. It would reduce transaction costs in export and domestic markets, making Zambian exports more competitive and reducing domestic consumer costs, which in turn should increase both total demand and farm incomes. D. Development constraints and strategy 1.22 Exploiting the untapped potential among smallholder, emergent, and commercial farmers would enable agriculture to play a significant role in employment creation and income growth and to provide the initial supply response needed to revitalize the economy. But realizing that potential will require overcoming the weaknesses in the policy environment and in support services that have constrained agriculture. Past economic policies emphasized public intervention through regulatory and institutional controls (including administrative pricing) and reliance on government-dominated cooperatives. These policies discouraged the private sector and led to a distorted crop mix, use of suboptimal technologies, and disinvestment from agriculture. Critical constraints on expansion and diversification of agriculture include low on-farm and agribusiness investment due to the disintegration of the agricultural credit system and high real interest rates; problems in access to land, which discourage long-term private investment in land; and poor rural transport network, which significantly increases the marketing costs of both agricultural inputs and outputs. 1.23 Reversing the past trend of low private investment in agriculture requires a different set of priorities. The Government recognizes that it needs to avoid actions that crowd out the private sector and that involve direct interference in and control of economic activities. The focus should be on creating an enabling policy environment and providing the infrastructure needed to induce private sector participation and investment. The Government has therefore embarked on an ambitious reform program aimed at sustaining improvements in the incentive structure through appropriate exchange rate and monetary policies, eliminating restrictions on the export of food grains, and formulating a land use and tenure policy to encourage long-term on-farm investments and optimal use of land in large and small farms. 1.24 As experience in Zambia and other countries has shown, however, policy reforms alone are often insufficient to generate adequate volume of private sector activity, especially when, as in Zambia, it has been suppressed over a long period. To encourage the private sector to fully exploit the policy reforms described above, high-quality and relevant support services must be provided to farmers and other private sector actors. Government agricultural agencies need to be able to provide such services on a timely basis and without costly subsidization. That requires a decentralization of control so that decision-making, responsibility, and accountability reside at
 - 9 - the lowest levels of contact with beneficiaries, with those directly responsible for providing services. 1.25 The Government's strategy for agriculture is to harness the growth and employment potential of the entire sector, including smallholders, emerging commercial farming, and commercial farming. This strategic vision would focus on (i) commercializing and privatizing the remaining agricultural parastatals, agribusinesses, and state farms (only 4 of the 42 agricultural parastatals have been privatized); (ii) stimulating private investment in agriculture by improving access to credit and foreign exchange, providing effective technical and advisory services, and promoting foreign investment; (iii) prioritizing and rationalizing public sector involvement in agriculture to achieve greater efficiency; and (iv) forging a shared vision with donors on priorities for the agricultural sector development. To achieve this strategic vision, the Government has resolved to operationalize its strategy through a comprehensive and coordinated agricultural sector program, which it has presented to donors for support. E. Donor assistance strategy 1.26 The goal of IDA and other donors' activities in Zambia is to assist the Government in achieving sustainable economic growth and in reducing poverty. The latest Country Assistance Strategy for Zambia was reviewed by the Board on March 10, 1994. The country strategy proposes to assist Zambia in three main areas, all related to the overall goal of poverty reduction: (i) stimulating growth by removing policy constraints and improving the enabling environment, including fiscal management; (ii) promoting private sector development and greater public sector efficiency; and (iii) supporting targeted interventions for the poor and vulnerable groups. The Agricultural Sector Investment Program forms a key component to the country strategy. Improving household food security and income is critical to meeting these objectives, and support for agriculture is thus a key element of the country strategy. The reforms supported by this program would improve the management of fiscal resources, substantially increase public sector efficiency, and provide necessary incentives needed to stimulate private investment in agriculture. In addition, the program would focus on smallholder farmers and thus would especially benefit the poor, particularly women, by raising their incomes through higher productivity and employment creation. F. Program performance and lessons learned 1.27 A country portfolio performance review undertaken in March 1994 highlighted a number of lessons for project implementation in Zambia. First, the proliferation of donor-assisted projects and over-reliance on foreign technical assistance undermine public sector management capacity and government commitment to implementing programs. Second, executing projects through overcentralized agencies does not work, and public sector decentralization is essential. Third, creating separate, or parallel, structures for implementing also is ineffective. Instead, the planning, disbursement, accounting, procurement, and monitoring and evaluation functions of the government line ministries must be upgraded, and donors must be encouraged to channel support through existing government agencies rather than introducing their own procedures. Fourth, subsidized credit undermines the viability of Zambia's three rural financial institutions. And fifth, the rigid designs of earlier projects prevented their adaptation to unforeseen changes during implementation. The ASIP is designed to address all these concerns. 1.28 To ensure that the program is implemented effectively and achieves the desired results, the ASIP will be implemented within the MAFF's institutional framework with minimum technical
 - 10 - assistance. Indeed, the ASIP will be carried out with maximum involvement and "ownership" by the Government and the beneficiaries to ensure that the program's development impact is sustained. And to ensure the relevance of program interventions, the program includes annual beneficiary assessments (see box 6). 1.29 The concern that the proliferation of uncoordinated donor programs in several sectors is overloading the Government's implementation capacity has prompted the development of integrated sectoral approaches in agriculture, health, and, more recently, education. These integrated programs are based on a strategic investment plan prepared by the Government, which all donors (including IDA) support. Development of these programs has required substantial coordination and capacity building up front, but that work is expected to substantially enhance the benefits of the jointly agreed sector programs. II. THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR INVESTMENT PROGRAM A. Concept 2.1 The proposed Agricultural Sector Investment Program (ASIP) is a departure from the traditional project approach. The ASIP is designed to achieve significantly greater project efficiency, ownership, capacity building, and sustainability. Seven features of the ASIP differentiate it from traditional projects. It covers the entire country's agricultural sector. It has been prepared by a Zambian task force with members drawn from both the public and the private sector. It will be implemented within the institutional framework of the Ministry of Agriculture, Food, and Fisheries (MAFF), without separate subprogram units. It will be financed by all donors active in the sector and the donors' procedures for procurement, reporting, accounting, and auditing would be standardized as much as possible. The use of long-term expatriate technical assistance would be kept to a minimum, and short-term technical assistance would be supplied on demand from the ASIP implementors. Poverty and malnutrition continue to be serious problems in Zambia, even by the African standards. Malnutrition is a leading cause of death among children. Many Zambians have insecure access to food and cannot obtain enough to sustain physical and mental growth. In rural areas food insecurity stems mainly from the low productivity of farms. The problem of urban food insecurity is less complex (mainly caused by low incomes), but no easier to solve. To deal with both emergency and chronic food insecurity, the Government is developing broad, comprehensive interministerial response mechanisms. Although these farmers are expected to benefit from the economic liberalization achieved under the structural adjustment program, their limited technology and poor access to markets impose severe constraints on their ability to expand their market share. By targeting research and extension services to benefit smallholders the ASIP would help these farmers improve their productivity. That in turn would lead to the production of marketable surpluses that not only would increase small farmers' incomes, but also would encourage private sector marketing. Thus, focusing on smallholders, the ASIP would be likely to raise the incomes of a large proportion of the rural poor through its effects on productivity and employment creation. 4.5 The holistic nature of the ASIP and the difficulty of measuring the benefits from specific subsectoral investments make it impossible to quantify its expected rates of return. Instead, a break-even analysis of the investments is used to assess whether the benefits required to justify the program are feasible. This analysis shows that at the discounted cost stream of 12 percent, the program would need to result in an annual growth rate in agricultural GDP of 0.84 percent. (This growth would need to be directly attributable to the ASIP and exclude the results from increases in other inputs.) If the cost of the ASIP increased by 10 percent, the minimum incremental growth in agricultural GDP directly attributable to the ASIP would have to be 0.93 percent. If the benefits lag by one year, the minimum growth rate would need to be 0.94, and if by two years 1.05 percent. (See annex 9 for the details of this quantitative analysis.) Under all reasonable risk scenarios, and given historical growth rates and the large gap between current levels of output and the production frontier, such increases in agricultural growth are achievable. The agricultural sector achieved an average growth rate of 3.3 percent between 1980 and 1992 under extremely adverse macroeconomic conditions. In addition, smallholders, currently producing about a third as much per hectare as commercial farmers, offer a considerable margin for improvement. B. Environmental sustainability 4.6 The ASIP would have positive environmental effects through its support for improved farming and conservation practices. Its investments would be focused on such efforts as minimum tillage, research on sustainable farming systems, and promotion of insitu soil and water conservation. As a land-surplus country, Zambia has the potential for the sustainable expansion of cultivated area on which the projections of its agricultural growth are in part based. In addition, the National Environmental Action Plan to be implemented concurrently with the ASIP,
 - 39 - will restrict cultivation in environmentally sensitive areas. An Environmental Support Program under preparation in the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources will also improve environment-related institutional capacity in the country and address specific environmental issues. Under the ASIP the purchase of agricultural inputs and chemicals deemed environmentally unacceptable would not be permitted, and an environmental mitigation plan has been developed to address any adverse environmental impact (see annex 11). C. Risks 4.7 The ASIP could face many challenges during implementation. These challenges might include inadequate funding of the Government's share of local costs, failure to decentralize decisionmaking to local levels, failure by the donors to dovetail their projects into the program, and derailment of the macroeconomic reform program. 4.8 Inadequate funding of local capital and recurrent costs due to unforeseen shortfalls in government revenue or failure to integrate annual ASIP expenditures into the budget process could lead to an erratic flow of funds and would greatly diminish implementation capacity. But shifting from a project to a program approach would (a) minimize the duplication of activities, thus releasing some resources to fund priority activities, and (b) permit the Government to anticipate revenues and overall budget envelopes, thereby permitting more rational prioritizing and programming of funds for the coming year. This holistic approach to sector management would also improve the ability to forecast resource requirements and thus make it easier for the Treasury to provide adequate resources. And the proposed annual review of the ASIP would help to integrate annual programs into the budget process. 4.9 The success of programs such as the ASIP depends on decentralizing decision making on development priorities and expenditure allocations so that beneficiaries participate in the process. Failure to decentralize perpetuates the inertia of bureaucratic practices and risks the continuation of "business as usual." The Government is fully aware of this risk and proposes a decentralized implementation structure for the ASIP. It also proposes to establish a systematic process for obtaining beneficiaries' views of the program. These actions should help to maintain the ASIP's focus. 4.10 Donors and the Government agree that managing a portfolio of more than 180 projects places an unsustainable demand on the MAFF's limited managerial capacity. Most donors have expressed interest in restructuring their projects to fit into the ASIP framework, and there is broad agreement that this should be done over a transition period of two to three years. Failure to merge these projects into the ASIP would greatly undermine its potential benefits. The Government is preparing a time-bound program for this restructuring. 4.11 The success of ASIP depends above all on the continuation of the economic and institutional reforms being implemented under the country's structural adjustment program, and of the macroeconomic policy, which supports increased reliance on the private sector and fiscal discipline to provide the resources for development. Although the Government of Zambia has maintained its commitment to reform under difficult circumstances and there are no obvious reasons that it might want to change course, the level of government commitment could nevertheless change as a result of the national elections expected near the end of 1996. IDA will maintain a close and continuing dialogue with all major actors on the economic and political scene in Zambia so as to be able to anticipate major shifts in policy and take corrective action.

In anticipation of local elections this year and national elections in 1996, the cabinet might authorize spending in excess of revenues. But the Government's exemplary record of fiscal discipline suggests that this risk is small. Even the unlikely event of change in government is not expected to derail the reform agenda because there is broad public recognition that a return to high inflation would be disastrous. Dear Sir, RE: ZAMBIA-AGRICULTURAL SECTOR LETTER OF DEVELOPMENT POLICY 1.0 Introduction Zambia has great potential and opportunities for increasing agricultural production given its abundant natural resources (land and water). As such the government accords significant importance to the agricultural sector's potential contribution to GDP and export earnings, as well as employment creation and income generation. The importance of the sector also lies in the fact that a large segment of the population is dependent on the sector with about 50 percent of the population depending on agriculture for their livelihood and 67 percent of the labor force employed in the sector. The purpose of this letter is to brief you on the major constraints to realization of the sector's full potential and current government policies, strategies and programs to address these problems. 2.0 Past and Present Policy Developments Zambia's past economic policies were too restrictive and constraining as there was too much control and interference on the part of government. This together with inadequate provision of essential public services resulted in unrealized potential for the sector. This was especially serious in agriculture because of the controls on crop and input prices, high level of parastatal activity in both marketing and input supply, and high maize and fertilizer subsidies. The past strategy for developing small-scale farmers relied on subsidized credit for inputs and marketing. These policies and strategies were obviously not sustainable; and some of the discernible side effects include the following: a poorly developed agricultural sector dominated by a single crop maize; huge Government expenditure on subsidies which contributed to inflationary budget deficits; insolvent public marketing and farm financing agents; very low farm productivity and incomes among small scale farmers; absence of private sector participation in the areas of farm input supply, agricultural marketing and food processing; and eroded household food security. Clearly, this scenario had to be reversed and corrected. Though attempts towards market liberalization began as far back as the early 1980s, it was not until November, 1991 when the MMD came into office that implementation of Structural Adjustment Program (SAP) gained momentum. Since then, the Government of Zambia has adopted a vastly different approach to economic policies from that which prevailed in the past decades. In the main, Zambia has undergone radical changes in the macro economic environment following the implementation of SAP which primarily attempts to transform the Zambian economy from a highly regulated one to one which is diversified and essentially driven by market forces. The economic policy and institutional reforms embodied in the program are intended to enhance more efficient resource allocation and improve the growth prospects in the economy. The Government has made substantial progress in achieving and restoring financial and monetary stability.
 - 43 - ANSEX-I Page 2 of 9 This has mainly involved decontrol of interest rates and prices, deregulation of exchange rates, introduction of open treasury bill sales, government cash budget and generally tightening of money supply growth in the economy, and a good revenue collection system. These measures, however, have created new dynamics which are changing the conditions for conducting economic activities , but have also resulted in a difficult economic and political transition, one characterized by a very tight monetary and fiscal policy, coupled with high unemployment. However, the Government is strongly committed to, and believes that the successful implementation of economic reforms combined with increased transparency and accountability are essential ingredients in improving returns to investment, general economic efficiency, growth and well-being of the Zambian people. Clearly, with macro-economic stability the foundation has been created for positive real growth in the economy. In line with SAP implementation, the agricultural sector is also undergoing liberalization with emphasis on input supply and crop marketing (both domestic and international), agricultural pricing, withdrawal of Government subsidies and privatization of agricultural parastatals. Government has laid its goals and objectives in the "Framework for Agricultural Policies to the year 2000 and Beyond", and later the "Statement of Agricultural Policies". The agricultural sector is expected to meet five broad goals, namely, national and household food security, income and employment generation, maintenance and improvement of the existing agricultural resource base, contribution to sustainable industrial development, and expanded contribution to national balance of payments by expanding agricultural exports. Despite these efforts, the agricultural supply response has not been robust. Recent performance has been characterized by fluctuations in production and uncertainty in the marketing in both produce and inputs as a result of radical changes that have occurred in the macro-economic and sector specific policies. However, this situation is expected to be temporary because in the medium to long term, farmers and traders should adjust to new economic conditions. Other factors besides economic policy shocks have also contributed to the unsatisfactory performance of the sector in recent years. These include a poor agricultural credit system and recurrent droughts. The agricultural lending institutions have been unable to meet the high demand for credit and have also performed poorly in terms of loan recoveries. The government has recently completed a study of the agricultural credit system which recommended phasing out general credit subsidies, rationalizing institutional roles and restructuring Lima Bank - the main government owned agricultural credit bank. The challenges are to ensure that the majority of our small scale farmers have access to financial services needed to finance agricultural activities and that a more viable and sustainable agricultural credit system is put in place. Drought effects have adversely affected the growth of the sector in recent years. During 1991/92 Zambia suffered severe drought which left farmers with little or no crops to sell and immensely depleted livestock levels. As a result, the sector's contribution to GDP fell by as much as 5 percent during the 1991/92 drought and by 1 percent during the 1993/94 drought.
 - 44 - ANNE 1- Page 3 of 9 3.0 Strategies and Actions The government intends to intensify its reliance on the private sector and free markets as the engines of growth. Government and the private sector will play specific but complimentary roles. Already, many former government functions are now being privatized and Government intends to restructure public activities to support and complement the efforts of the private sector. It is recognized that like everywhere else in the world, the full development of the agricultural sector depends upon both public and private sector effort and involvement. In order to achieve the goals outlined above, the main policy thrusts will include: liberalizing agricultural markets; privatizing and supporting private sector development; agricultural diversification; placing emphasis on services to smallholders; implementing special actions to support food security; helping to revitalize rural financial services; and making better use of available farming land (see attached Policy Matrix). Liberalization of Agricultural Markets: Positive steps have already been taken in this direction and it is an on-going process. The policy of Government is to reinforce this process of liberalization by among other things, relying increasingly on market based prices for all crops; lifting restrictions/ constraints to domestic and international trade; reviewing and where necessary changing the relevant pieces of legislation; and privatizing agricultural parastatals. Increasing the Role of the Private Sector: The government is fully committed to rolling back the extensive involvement of the public sector in economic activities. A number of enterprises have been privatized including; Poultry Processing Company, Zambia Maltings Ltd, Nanga Farms Limited and Agricultural Farming Equipment Limited (AFE). Several others are at an advanced stage of the privatization process. These include; Zambia Agricultural Development Ltd. Farms i.e. Chilongolo, Chainda, Hartley, Simmenthal and Holding farms and the Zambia Sugar Company Ltd. The Zambia Privatization Agency (ZPA) continues to prepare eligible public enterprises for sale. When completed, all the marketing and processing will be handled by the private sector. There are also a number of services provided by the public sector including for instance, veterinary services for which the government will seek increased cost recovery and outright privatization where the conditions are appropriate. Agricultural Diversification: In view of difficulties in growing and marketing crops such as maize in some regions, Government is encouraging farmers to expand their crop portfolio so as to improve their income base by growing high value crops which can easily be marketed and require less external inputs and takes into account agro-ecological considerations. Some of the main economic activities include growing of crops such as groundnuts, sunflower, soyabeans, tobacco and cotton. Other economic activities include fish farming, poultry, piggeries, horticultural and flower growing in the peri-urban areas. The diversity in outputs will help reduce risk by broadening income sources and thus enhancing household food security. Improving Services to Smallholders: Taken as a group, Zambia's smallholders constitute a large under-utilized resource in the economy. However, the quality of publicly funded agricultural support services require significant improvement. In the areas of research, extension services, marketing, credit and land tenure the Government will make special efforts to ensure that smallholders have full opportunity
 - 45 - ANNEX-1 Page 4 of 9 to share in the economic growth and development that is emerging under the new policy environment. Some of the measures include making available appropriate and affordable yield enhancing technologies; and availability of, and access to key inputs especially improved seeds, fertilizer and finance as well as enhancing institutional capacities for land administration and surveys. Government is also putting a special emphasis on ecologically sound farming practices to minimize unsustainable exploitation of the natural resource base. This will be achieved by among other measures, technical messages on appropriate crop rotation and diversification, and on integrating agro-forestry into farming systems. Furthermore, improved management of available water and moisture can make a major contribution to improving productivity of smallhaolder farmers and can help contribute to higher incomes and improved food security. Wherever technically and economically feasible, small scale irrigation will be developed to help increase cropping intensity and increase farm incomes. Improving the Economic Status of Women: Women constitute nearly two-thirds of the rural population in Zambia and account for over three-quarters of the agricultural labor supply. They also supply about 80 percent of the labor required for household food processing and haulage of farm produce, water and fuelwood within households. However, women farmers have benefitted little from government supported agricultural services such as extension and credit. In order to change this situation, agricultural research, extension, credit, and land tenure policies will be structured so as to enhance the economic status of women in the sector. Making Better Use of Available Natural Resources: Zambia is a land surplus country and most communities have easy access to traditional land. The main obstacles in these areas is the lack of transport infrastructure. Many of these areas will become dynamic sources of growth as they become more accessible. Access to land in areas close to the major transport corridors and in peri-urban areas is slow and cumbersome. Land registration in areas where title deeds are available is very slow and the law did not allow land subdivision for those who had surplus land to sell. Furthermore, recent surveys show that at least (a third) of the land on large commercial farms is unutilized. The government has therefore drafted legal reforms to the land tenure systems, and it is hoped that once enacted it would improve land administration, allow subdivision and attract increased investment. Furthermore, a large number of Zambians are food insecure.To tackle these problems, government is developing broad and comprehensive inter-ministerial response mechanisms to deal with emergency and chronic food insecurity. Government will deal with transitory food insecurity through a national food reserve of one million bags and a financial mechanism to finance imports. In so doing, ASIP seeks to make much more effective use of all public funds from both donors and the Government.  - 58 - ANNEX-5 Page 1 of 6 ZAMBIA AGRICULTURAL SECTOR INVESTMENT PROGRAM Financial Management Unit As the Agriculture Sector Investment Program (ASIP) is a government program, it will be implemented using the government procedures of planning, budgeting, accounting, internal control and financial management. The weaknesses of these systems is a source of concern to the donors who believe the current system would not ensure full accountability of their funds. The government system has a number of critical problems. First, there is little relationship between plan objectives and budgetary allocations. Secondly, the provincial level commonly forms a bottleneck in the flow of funds to the districts. The current system where funds are disbursed from the Ministry of Finance through the office of the Provincial Permanent Secretary to the Provincial Agricultural Officer and the Provincial Accounting Officer and then to the district level has many levels for leakage of funds. Due to the failure of the Ministry of Finance to disburse the funds budgeted in the annual budget (Yellow Book), the Provincial Accounting Units (PACU) may not allocate these funds fairly between departments. Finally, funds allocated to the Provincial Agricultural Office may be absorbed at the provincial rather than field level. These problems are exacerbated by the complex financial regulations which focus is on control rather than accountability. All funds are kept at the provincial level except for small cash imprests held by the district. Districts face considerable bureaucratic hurdles to have funds released and generally have little autonomy over their own expenditures. Often districts do not know how much their annual budget allocation is or how much of it is spent. The objective under ASIP is to ensure that there is full accountability for both government and donor funds. Accountability would enable both the Government and donors to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the programs, ensure funds are used for the purpose for which intended, and that they reach the intended beneficiaries. Such accountability demands a different system of relationships from those noted above. The most significant one is the need to make the district level more accountable. Accountability implies the power to control events, which the districts do not have. With power to control their own expenses, the districts can be held accountable for their financial performance. The question of decentralization and devolution of fiscal controls to district levels is critical to the success of ASIP, and the Government is urged to complete the restructuring of the Ministry of Agriculture Food and Fisheries (MAFF) and provide interim guidelines for decentralization pending completion of the reform. The MAFF has appointed the accounting firm Price Waterhouse to design a financial management and accounting system which would also meet the information and accountability requirements of different donors. The consultants' first report is expected at the end of October 1994. If MAFF adopts the report's recommendations, implementation of the new system could start on a pilot basis before the year-end. Until a system acceptable to the donors is in place and has been tried and tested, the donors have agreed to maintain their respective financial management and accounting arrangements for the ongoing projects. Transitional arrangements need to be in place for the transactions under ASIP.

Initially, the FMU would introduce tight controls on matters such as procurement where procurement limits for the districts would be low. On a monthly basis, the units would provide information to sub-program managers on transactions for the various sub-programs which the managers can use to assess their programs, and reconcile with their own information. The System The objective of the proposed system is to ensure that funds reach the intended beneficiaries, and that different donors can monitor their contributions. Funds would be disbursed from the Donor Funds division at headquarters direct to either the program or the district accounting unit, with a detailed breakdown of the allocation to the various programs based on the program budgets and donor contributions. A copy of the allocation would be sent directly to the manager of a sub-program to ensure that the program management is aware of the funds allocated to it. The accounting units would maintain cashbooks to record all donor cash movements under ASIP and open subsidiary ledgers for each program. All payments would be made by the accounting unit upon receipt of proper authorization by the program managers and district and/or provincial agricultural officers as appropriate. At the end of each month, the accountants would prepare an expenditure summary by program from the cash book and the ledgers. The monitoring function for unretired imprests would be at the district level. No new funds would be disbursed before retirement of all imprests and the receipt by the FMU of the expenditure summary. The expenditure summaries prepared by the district accountants would be forwarded to program managers and the Donor Funds division at the FMU, showing the comparisons between the budgeted and actual expenditures and the cash balances available for the sub-programs. The FlMU would check the validity of the expenses, compare them to budgets, and use the summaries as a basis for the preparation of withdrawal applications. The Role of the Internal Audit Department The Internal Audit Department would play an important role in the system to ensure that funds reach the intended beneficiaries and are used for purposes for which intended. The progress and impact of individual ASIP sub-programs will need to be monitored and evaluated regularly so that timely adjustments can be made. Also, insofar as ASIP covers the entire agricultural sector, decision-makers will want to know periodically about the overall performance of the agricultural sector and the contributions of individual sub-sectors (sub- programs) to that performance. ASIP's M&E will have three components: (i) management information systems (MIS), (ii) impact evaluations of individual sub-programs and beneficiary assessments and feedback, and (iii) sector performance analysis. MIS 3. A study is being commissioned to work out the details of the MIS which will be established in each sub-program. Since the MIS is a management tool, the design of each sub- program will take account of the organizational structure of the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries (MAFF) and the corresponding functional responsibilities. In the context of the planned decentralization, particular attention will be paid to the reporting system and to ensure the smooth flow of information on the implementation of various sub-programs to managers at different levels (the Ministry, provinces, districts, camps). As the information requirements in terms of coverage and detail will vary from one level to the next, emphasis will be on determining precisely what information different decision-makers need and providing this information so as not to overwhelm them with extraneous detail. For instance, a manager at a lower level where implementation occurs will require detailed information on individual activities, as it is at this level that any corrective action which may be needed will have to be taken. On the other hand, a department director at the Ministry responsible for an entire sub-sector is less likely to be concerned with the operational details underlying individual activities, and more with the aggregate contributions of individual activities to the performance of the sub-sector. Also, a feedback mechanism will be instituted in conjunction with the MIS to ensure that managers utilize the information supplied to them. The MIS will provide information on physical, personnel and financial inputs as well as outputs; the performance indicators defined in the ASIP sub-program preparation reports will be used to monitor sub-program outputs. One will utilize quantitative data to measure the impact of the services and

The other component, systematic client consultation, will comprise feedback from the intended beneficiaries on the effectiveness of these sub-programs in terms of their design features.  -72 - ANNEX - 9 Page 1 of 7 ZAMBIA AGRICULTURAL SECTOR INVESTMENT PROGRAM Economic Analysis Introduction 1. Normal Bank practice is to derive economic rates of return for agricultural projects and programs using farm models. Estimates are made of the frequency of adoption of each of the farm models over the life of the project and the net income gain from adopting each model to calculate the aggregate net benefit stream. The benefit stream is then compared to the project cost stream to derive the ex-ante rate of return. At the end of the project the ex-ante rate of return is recalculated based on M & E data on project imiplementation and adoption rates of the models, changes in prices and changes in project costs. Years later an impact evaluation may be done where actual on farm performance is measured via farm surveys, a step not done in the recalculated returns. 2. For ASIP another procedure is proposed. Given the sector-wide coverage and the large number of sub-programs involved, determining an economic return using this approach would entail the calculation of dozens of model farms, with insurmountable quality control problems. On the other hand, the sector wide M&E program opens up the possibility to advance the evaluation by years, since it is based on an annual survey of farms carried out by the Central Statistics Office of the Government of Zambia. These surveys can be used to evaluate the impact of the program with only a one or two year lag. A project completion report should therefore be able to compute an actual rate of return of the program, based for example on what happened by the third year and projections based on them for the fourth and subsequent years. 3. The economic analysis of the program is therefore proposed in two steps. The ex-ante analysis will be performed using a break even analysis of the incremental cost and benefit streams at the national level. The ex-post analysis will be based on an econometric estimation of actual rates of return to rural households from ASIP investments using data from the M&E surveys and the projections based on them. Zambia's agriculture is predominantly rain-fed and rainfall is one of the major determinants of sector performance in any given year. Despite abundant, unused high potential soil and abundant water resources, sectoral growth is sluggish and rural poverty pervasive. Zambian farmers have not been able to take advantage of the available natural resources. 2. Zambia has an estimated 9 million ha, or 12 percent of its total land area, suitable for cultivation and 16 million ha suitable for rangeland grazing. However, only about 1.3 million ha (or 14 percent of the available arable area) is presently cultivated. The irrigable potential is conservatively estimated at 430,000 ha, of which no more than 50,000 ha is developed, mostly on commercial farms for sugar, wheat and plantation crops. Most of the land is farmed by the private sector, either by smallholders or commercial farmers. Land tenure security is quite good, but land is not easily tradeable, sub-divided or sub-leased to small farmers. There are also long delays in land titling and other matters of land administration, frustrating private investors. While cultivable land is abundant in areas close to infrastructure, it is not sufficiently accessible to smallholders. All land is vested in the President who has delegated the land administration function to the Commissioner of Lands. About 4 million ha are classified as State Land and administered by the Commissioner of Lands; 68 million ha (or 91 percent of the total land area) are classified as Trust and Reserve Land, access to which is governed by customary law and institutions. 3. Zambia can be divided into three broad agro-ecological zones. Zone 1, which is mainly located in southern areas of Southern and Western Provinces, has low agricultural potential, with a sparse population of less than half a million, poorly distributed annual rainfall of about 600 mm, and low fertility soils. Furthermore, widespread incidence of trypanosomiasis and other diseases limits livestock production. Zone 2 covers the central belt of the country. It is the most populous zone, with over 4 million inhabitants and has the highest agricultural potential. It has a well distributed annual rainfall of between 800 to 1000 mm, and generally good soils. Zone 3 covers large areas of Northern, Luapula and North-Western Provinces and has a population of over 3.5 million. Although this zone has annual rainfall in excess of 1000 mm, problems of soil acidity and low fertility, combined with low solar radiation levels due to cloud cover, limit yields. In addition, .his zonle is not suitable for cattle rearing. 4. 'T he approximately 700,000 farmers in Zambia can be grouped into three main categories. About 75 percenti are smallholders with an average farm size of 2 ha who typically cultivate with hand tools for subsistence. An estimated 17 percent are "emerging" commercial farmers with farms betwveen 10-2() ha in size, who employ animal draft power and hired labor for cultivation, use farm inputs (improved seeds and fertilizer), and produce significant marketable surpluses. The balance of 8 percent are larger commercial farmers with farm sizes exceeding 60 ha and account for about 60 percent of the marketed output. The commercial farmers are mainly located along the Line-of-Rail or near major urban centers and produce a range of livestock and crop products mainly lor the domestic market. In nrral areas 65 percent of the population are women

In the smallholder sub-sector, women play a major role in both farm management and in the provision of labor. 5. Maize dominates Zambian agriculture, accounting for about 76 percent of the cropped area. This concentration on a single crop is a result of years of input subsidies, directed agricultural services and guaranteed prices, as well as large consumer subsidies that have inflated demand for maize products. Until recently, improved seed for maize was readily available at subsidized prices and the entire marketing chain for maize was publicly supported through a network of parastatals. Cotton and groundnuts each account for 8 percent of the cultivated area. Soya bean and sunflower are emerging as new field crops, with tobacco and wheat important in the commercial sector. The national livestock herd comprises 2.6 million head of cattle; 0.5 million head of sheep and goats; 0.3 million pigs and 4.3 million poultry. Eighty percent of cattle and over 90 percent of sheep, goats and pigs are in the smallholder sector, whereas over 50 percent of poultry are managed commercially. The Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries (MAFF) is organized on hierarchical lines with most budgetary, financial, and many regulatory and administrative functions centralized at MAFF headquarters. Responsibility for the management of technical services tends to be decentralized to provincial, district and research station levels, but without corresponding delegation of administrative and financial powers. This leads to inefficiencies and a general lack of accountability for performance at provincial and district levels. A detailed MAFF organization chart is attached in Annex 3. The Minister of Agriculture is assisted by two deputy ministers, one for Agriculture and the other for Food Security, and by a civil service headed by the Permanent Secretary. The Permanent Secretary of MAFF is assisted by a deputy permanent secretary and six departments: policy and planning; fisheries; agriculture; veterinary services; seed control and certification; and a national agricultural information service. The MAFF also administers a number of parastatals including Lima Bank, Zamseed, Natco, Lintco, and the Dairy Produce Board. The MAFF offers agricultural services, mainly to smallholders, through nine provincial and sixty two district offices. The most extensive and heavily staffed departments include those for Agricultural Extension and Research and Veterinary Services. Other sections of MAFF, such as the Irrigation and Mechanization and Farm Power units, are small and act mainly as technical support units to field extension operations. As policies to privatize the parastatal companies are implemented, MAFF should progressively reduce the number of technical support units to minimize redundancy. 7. Apart from the services of MAFF, several other ministries of the Government and parastatal organizations are significantly involved in the agricultural sector. The Zambia Bureau of Standards (ZABS), a statutory body under the Ministry of Commerce, Trade and Industry, is responsible for national standards including those for agriculture. As Zambia's current policy is to promote exports and access to information on required standards in other countries, the work of ZBS will become increasingly important. The Ministry of Lands (MOL) controls land affairs,

Historically, management of land affairs has been highly centralized and inefficient, and past attempts to decentralize have been frustrated by lack of funds and qualified staff. A large cooperative infrastructure which is heavily influenced, and often de facto controlled by the Government, is comprised of about 2000 primary cooperative societies at the grassroots level, district and provincial unions at the secondary level, and the Zambian Cooperative Federation (ZCF) at the national level. This cooperative structure has historically been involved in a wide range of support activities, from input and credit supply through marketing and storage, with limited success. 8. In some sub-sectors, where government controls have been limited, the private sector has demonstrated some dynamism, for example in the areas of horticulture, legumes, coffee, and poultry. Exchange rate reforms and market liberalization policies under the structural adjustment program have greatly facilitated these private sector activities. The commercial farming sector, represented by the Zambian National Farmers Union and several affiliated producer associations, is developing new markets, especially exports. These producer associations are also developing new cooperative ventures that are producer controlled, especially in the supply of fertilizers, chemicals and farm machinery. There is also increased private sector activity in seed production and supply. These initiatives are the beginning of a process that has been delayed by pervasive government intervention which created uncertainty in markets, but it is now being rapidly dismantled by the adjustment program.

doc.abstracts: The Agricultural Sector Investment Program (ASIP) will be implemented over a four year period and has four main components. The first, policy and institutional improvements , will focus on outstanding policy reforms in key areas of marketing (eliminating subsidies to marketing parastatals), trade and pricing, food security, and land use and land tenure. The second component will undertake public investment to complement and support the policy and institutional improvements. The third component, private sector development, will help create an enabling environment and incentives for the private sector. Finally, the fourth component, pilot investment schemes, will establish a rural investment fund to support small-scale capital investments in rural communities on a matching grant basis and it would support the privatization of government farms.
